passages.text: Foreign Exchange - Global
We remain long the 10yr ACGB vs US10yr and received 2s5s10s.
Long 10yr ACGB versus US 10yr - we now target - 20bp by end- November; conviction 3/5. Receive AU2s5s10s fly - we now target - 15bp by end- November; conviction 3/5.

We have been holding two Australia rates trades (above) for some time. We usually comment on these each week in our global Key Strategy and Themes publication, but feel that a more detailed update is overdue. In short, both trades have been struggling a little of late, but we elect to hold them, with updated targets and extended timelines.

This trade primarily reflects "structural" arguments. In particular, we continue to see risks of higher US term premia and higher real yields, given the unpredictable and unconventional policy landscape under Trump. We also see risk that US inflation fears could rise, due to both Trump's threats to Fed independence and tariff- related impacts still to flow through to US CPI inflation over coming months. Global investors and reserve managers are heavily exposed to the US government bonds, and we do see risk that flows could tilt away from that market. Our team's tracking of such flows certainly does not suggest that global investors are abandoning that market, but inflows have become less consistent.
Fig. 1: 10yr ACGB versus US 10yr
Fig. 2: AU5y5y versus US5y5y

At the same time, we think that global flow into ACGBs should remain strong. Australia does not face the issues noted above, and has far superior deficit and debt metrics. The Australian bond market has grown over recent years, but we think this is creating more global interest. On the flow side, Australian BOP data (albeit dated) show strong global buying of AUD bonds, and more recent Japan BOP data show that interest from Japan has rebounded over more recent months. Our feedback from a recent visit with Tokyo investors revealed strong interest in AUD bonds.

We think that the challenge for this position has been more "cyclical", in particular recent data flow and developments. These include (in order) the softer US payrolls report in early August, Powell's somewhat dovish communication from Jackson Hole, and this week's higher Australia July CPI indicator report, which we think contained some signal but also some noise. These developments have seen US rates outperform Australian rates recently.
Some of the market concerns related to the longer end of the US curve have also been more reflected in the 30yr than in the 10yr. Trades like 5yr- 30yr steepeners appear popular.

Another challenge for this trade could be positioning - we have received little pushback on our view of ACGB outperformance, including from Japan, suggesting that this trade might be somewhat crowded. However, our sense is that investors may be more likely to add to, or initiate this position at current levels, rather than stop out. The 5y5y cross market spread (Fig. 2) is another popular expression of these themes, and often appears to trade within a range, being "policed" by investors, who frequently seem to fade extremes, anticipating mean reversion. At current levels, we think that investors are more likely to initiate or add to such trades, rather than stop out.

We give less weight to historical/seasonal patterns, but do note that US data often outperforms consensus expectations in September (as does USD), while Australian data often underperforms. The 10yr spread often narrows in September.

More significantly, we judge that our thinking on short- end rates also supports our trade. The US strip is pricing a lower terminal rate than our US economists expect. Our US team forecast 25bp rate cuts in September, December and March. This is roughly priced currently, but the US strip goes further, pricing a Fed Funds rate around \(3\%\) by end 2026. In contrast, the Australian strip appears to be pricing a tightening cycle, commencing from late 2026, which we do not expect. If the back half of the US strip moves to price less easing, and the back half of the Australian strip moves to price less tightening, we think this could support our trade.
We have been favouring the belly of the curve for several reasons:

We think that the forward strip (Fig. 3) is too steep. This appears to be pricing a too- high terminal rate, in our view, and appears to be reflecting market expectations for the resumption of an RBA rate hike cycle, which we are not forecasting. Our forecast is for the cash rate to be cut by 25bp in November and February, resulting in an unchanged terminal rate of \(3.10\%\) through at least 2026, if not beyond. The Australian fly appears attractive relative to the US fly (Fig. 4). The fly can trade somewhat directionally, and appears attractive relative to the level of 5yr yields, in our view (Fig. 5).

This trade has also performed less impressively than we had hoped. This might reflect general curve steepening witnessed this year, which has likely dragged the five- year yield higher. In addition, the pricing of a tightening cycle in Australia from late 2026 also appears to have impacted forward rates (Fig. 3) and may have held back the performance of the belly.
Fig. 3: Forward curve is steep
Fig. 5: AU2s5s10s fly versus 5yr swap rate
Fig. 4: Australia 2s5s10s fly versus US fly
Fig. 6: AU2s5s10s fly versus bank bill future
Fig. 7: Long 10yr ACGB (June 2035) versus US 10yr: target: -20bp by end-November; conviction:3/5)
Note: Conviction scale: 1 - Watch; 2 - Watch Closely; 3 - Positioned @ 1/3 desired; 4 - Positioned @ 2/3 desired; 5 - Positioned @ 100% desired. Source: Nomura
Fig. 8: Receive Australia 2s5s10s fly (target: -15bp by end-November; conviction: 3/5)
Note: Conviction scale: 1 - Watch; 2 - Watch Closely; 3 - Positioned @ 1/3 desired; 4 - Positioned @ 2/3 desired; 5 - Positioned @ 100% desired Source: Nomura, Bloomberg

Personnel: The fixed income research analysts of Nomura Securities International, Inc and its affiliates regularly interact with sales and trading desk personnel in connection with obtaining liquidity and pricing information for their respective coverage universe.

Nomura's Fixed Income Strategists express views on the price of securities and financial markets by providing trade recommendations. These can be relative value recommendations, directional trade recommendations, asset allocation recommendations, or a mixture of all three. The analysis which is embedded in a trade recommendation would include, but not be limited to: - Fundamental analysis regarding whether a security's price deviates from its underlying macro- or micro- economic fundamentals. - Quantitative analysis of price variations. - Technical factors such as regulatory changes, changes to risk appetite in the market, unexpected rating actions, primary market activity and supply/ demand considerations. The timeframe for a trade recommendation is variable. Tactical ideas have a short timeframe, typically less than three months. Strategic trade ideas have a longer timeframe of typically more than three months.
